questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for perforation of appendix except?

questions.text: A 3-day-old male neonate is brought to the neonatal ICU following a surgical procedure for congenital diaphragmatic hernia repair. While recovering in the postoperative ward, the neonate develops shallow breathing, hypotonia, and pinpoint pupils. The mother had an uncomplicated pregnancy and denied drug use. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Opioids used for analgesia in neonates can cause respiratory depression due to their immaturity of hepatic and respiratory systems. Pinpoint pupils and shallow breathing are hallmarks of opioid toxicity in neonates.
  • ➤ Opioids used for analgesia in neonates can cause respiratory depression due to their immaturity of hepatic and respiratory systems.
  • ➤ Pinpoint pupils and shallow breathing are hallmarks of opioid toxicity in neonates.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female is brought to the psychiatry clinic by her family with complaints of bizarre behavior over the past three months. She claims that she has been chosen by a divine force to save the world and frequently tells her family that she is in communication with celestial beings. Additionally, she reports that her neighbors are conspiring to harm her and interfere with her divine mission. Based on her symptoms, which type of delusion is she most likely experiencing?

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a blunt trauma to the perineal region sustained while straddling a bicycle. questions.text: A newborn dies shortly after birth, and the hydrostatic test shows partial lung aeration, with some lung pieces floating and others sinking. The autopsy reveals that the infant suffered from severe congenital pneumonia. What is the most likely mechanism behind the mixed hydrostatic test results?

options.label: A
options.text: Uneven gas exchange in the alveoli caused by areas of consolidated lung tissue

options.label: B
options.text: Delayed resuscitation efforts resulting in partial aeration of the lungs

options.label: C
options.text: Atelectasis in some lobes of the lung due to obstruction of the alveolar ducts

options.label: D
options.text: Decomposition gases causing a combination of false-positive and false-negative results

questions.correct_answer: A. Uneven gas exchange in the alveoli caused by areas of consolidated lung tissue
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Partial lung aeration on the hydrostatic test may occur in congenital pneumonia due to uneven gas exchange and areas of lung consolidation.
  • ➤ Partial lung aeration on the hydrostatic test may occur in congenital pneumonia due to uneven gas exchange and areas of lung consolidation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with profuse watery diarrhea resembling "rice water" stools, severe dehydration, and electrolyte imbalance. His symptoms are consistent with an infection leading to increased intestinal permeability. Damage to which of the following cellular structures is most likely responsible for the increased fluid loss?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zona occludens (tight junctions) are essential for maintaining epithelial barrier function by regulating paracellular transport. Disruption of tight junctions by bacterial toxins can lead to increased intestinal permeability and massive fluid loss, as seen in cholera-related rice-water diarrhea.
  • ➤ Zona occludens (tight junctions) are essential for maintaining epithelial barrier function by regulating paracellular transport.
  • ➤ Zona occludens (tight junctions)
  • ➤ Disruption of tight junctions by bacterial toxins can lead to increased intestinal permeability and massive fluid loss, as seen in cholera-related rice-water diarrhea.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with complaints of infertility and light menstrual periods for the past year. She has a history of multiple miscarriages that required dilation and curettage (D&C). Which diagnostic procedure is the most appropriate to confirm and potentially treat her condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hysteroscopy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's history of multiple miscarriages requiring dilation and curettage (D&C), along with symptoms of infertility and light menstrual periods (hypomenorrhea), is suggestive of Asherman syndrome (intrauterine adhesions). Intrauterine adhesions form due to trauma to the endometrium, commonly after repeated D&Cs.
  • • Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing and treating Asherman syndrome. It provides a direct view of the uterine cavity, enabling precise identification of adhesions and simultaneous adhesiolysis (removal of adhesions). This approach helps restore the endometrial cavity’s normal structure, improving the chances of conception and alleviating symptoms like hypomenorrhea.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pelvic ultrasound: Pelvic ultrasound is a non-invasive imaging method commonly used to evaluate the uterus and adnexa for abnormalities like fibroids or ovarian cysts. However, it cannot provide direct visualization of adhesions or intrauterine scarring, making it suboptimal for diagnosing Asherman syndrome. The adhesions may not always alter the thickness of the endometrium in a way that is visible on an ultrasound, limiting its diagnostic accuracy in this scenario.
  • • Option A. Pelvic ultrasound:
  • • Option B. MRI pelvis: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the pelvis provides detailed imaging of soft tissue structures and is effective in diagnosing complex uterine conditions like adenomyosis, fibroids, and congenital uterine anomalies. However, it is not typically the investigation of choice for evaluating suspected intrauterine adhesions, as it lacks the resolution needed to directly visualize intrauterine pathology and cannot be used for therapeutic purposes.
  • • Option B. MRI pelvis:
  • • Option C. Saline infusion sonography: Saline infusion sonography (sonohysterography) involves instilling saline into the uterine cavity to enhance visualization of the endometrial lining and detect abnormalities such as polyps or adhesions. While this method can detect adhesions as filling defects, it cannot provide direct visualization or treatment of adhesions. Hysteroscopy remains superior because it allows both diagnosis and immediate treatment.
  • • Option C. Saline infusion sonography:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for the diagnosis and treatment of intrauterine adhesions (Asherman syndrome), providing direct visualization of the uterine cavity and allowing for adhesiolysis in the same session.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is prescribed a fixed-dose combination (FDC) of drospirenone and ethinyl estradiol as an oral contraceptive. Three months into therapy, she develops mild hyperkalemia on routine bloodwork. Which property of drospirenone is most likely responsible for this finding?

options.label: C
options.text: Synergistic estrogenic effect with ethinyl Estradiol

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anti-mineralocorticoid action

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Drospirenone is a progestin with anti-mineralocorticoid activity that can cause mild hyperkalemia due to its potassium-retaining effects.
  • ➤ Drospirenone is a progestin with anti-mineralocorticoid activity that can cause mild hyperkalemia due to its potassium-retaining effects.

questions.text: A baby assessed at 5 minutes after birth had pink extremities, a heart rate of 99/min, strong crying, active movement, and responded to stimulation by crying. The APGAR score for this newborn is ________.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 9

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ APGAR scoring evaluates five objective signs at 1 and 5 minutes after birth: color, heart rate, respiration, muscle tone, and reflex irritability. A perfect score of 10 indicates a healthy and well-adapted newborn.
  • ➤ APGAR scoring evaluates five objective signs at 1 and 5 minutes after birth: color, heart rate, respiration, muscle tone, and reflex irritability. A perfect score of 10 indicates a healthy and well-adapted newborn.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of primary open-angle glaucoma and visually significant cataracts presents for surgical evaluation. His intraocular pressure remains uncontrolled despite maximal medical therapy, and he reports significant glare and visual impairment. A combined surgical approach is planned to address both conditions. Which of the following procedures is least likely to be included in the standard triple procedure for glaucoma?

options.label: B
options.text: Scleral fixation of the intraocular lens due to zonular instability

options.label: C
options.text: Posterior chamber intraocular lens implantation after cataract extraction

options.label: D
options.text: Extra-capsular cataract extraction to remove the opacified lens

questions.correct_answer: B. Scleral fixation of the intraocular lens due to zonular instability
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The triple procedure for glaucoma includes trabeculectomy, extra-capsular cataract extraction, and posterior chamber intraocular lens implantation. Additional modifications, such as scleral fixation of the intraocular lens, may be required in cases of anatomical abnormalities (e.g., zonular weakness) but are not standard components.
  • ➤ The triple procedure for glaucoma includes trabeculectomy, extra-capsular cataract extraction, and posterior chamber intraocular lens implantation.
  • ➤ Additional modifications, such as scleral fixation of the intraocular lens, may be required in cases of anatomical abnormalities (e.g., zonular weakness) but are not standard components.

questions.text: A study analyzing pressure-volume loops in different cardiac conditions observes a leftward shift in the loop. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A leftward shift of the pressure-volume loop indicates decreased ventricular compliance, commonly seen in aortic stenosis due to concentric left ventricular hypertrophy. This results in higher filling pressures and reduced end-diastolic volume.
  • ➤ A leftward shift of the pressure-volume loop indicates decreased ventricular compliance, commonly seen in aortic stenosis due to concentric left ventricular hypertrophy.
  • ➤ leftward shift
  • ➤ aortic stenosis
  • ➤ This results in higher filling pressures and reduced end-diastolic volume.

questions.text: Mr. Keerthi, 18-year-old man presents to the emergency department with retrosternal chest pain and pain with swallowing that started abruptly the previous morning and has progressively worsened. The pain is burning in nature and worse with swallowing solids. He has been limiting his diet to soft foods due to discomfort. His medical history includes frequent tension headaches for which he uses ibuprofen as needed. He smokes a half pack of cigarettes daily and drinks alcohol socially. His mother has Crohn disease. On examination, his temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg, and pulse is 88/min. There are no oropharyngeal lesions, lymphadenopathy, or abnormalities on lung auscultation, cardiac examination, or abdominal examination. Endoscopy was done and the image is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Recommend ibuprofen discontinuation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pill esophagitis should be suspected in patients with retrosternal chest pain and odynophagia, especially in the context of recent NSAID or other pill use. Management involves discontinuing the offending agent and advising on proper pill-swallowing techniques to prevent recurrence.
  • ➤ Pill esophagitis should be suspected in patients with retrosternal chest pain and odynophagia, especially in the context of recent NSAID or other pill use.
  • ➤ Management involves discontinuing the offending agent and advising on proper pill-swallowing techniques to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a 10-year history of Parkinson's disease is on levodopa/carbidopa therapy. Over the last few months, he has developed visual hallucinations and delusions. He denies suicidal ideation or harming others. His motor symptoms are well-controlled. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Quetiapine and clozapine are the preferred agents for treating psychosis in Parkinson's disease due to their minimal impact on motor function.
  • ➤ Quetiapine and clozapine are the preferred agents for treating psychosis in Parkinson's disease due to their minimal impact on motor function.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man with a history of asthma and chronic rhinosinusitis presents with shortness of breath. Three days ago, he developed an upper respiratory infection, followed by increased sinus headache and mild dyspnea. Despite using diphenhydramine, albuterol, ibuprofen, and his regular fluticasone/salmeterol inhaler, his dyspnea worsened over 3 hours. He has a history of nasal polyps and sinus surgeries. On examination, he is in mild respiratory distress with a pulse of 115/min and respirations of 23/min. Pulse oximetry shows 98% on 2L oxygen via nasal cannula. Rhinorrhea, diffuse bilateral wheezes, conjunctival injection, and facial erythema are noted. He is treated with methylprednisolone and albuterol nebulizations, leading to symptom improvement over 24 hours. In addition to tapering doses of prednisone, which of the following would most likely benefit this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Montelukast

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD) is associated with asthma, chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps, and NSAID sensitivity. Management includes leukotriene-modifying agents such as montelukast to improve airway inflammation and control symptoms.
  • ➤ Aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD) is associated with asthma, chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps, and NSAID sensitivity.
  • ➤ Management includes leukotriene-modifying agents such as montelukast to improve airway inflammation and control symptoms.

questions.text: In the electron transport chain, which of the following respiratory components directly interacts with molecular oxygen during oxidative phosphorylation?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cytochrome aa₃ (cytochrome c oxidase, complex IV) is the terminal electron acceptor in the electron transport chain and directly reacts with molecular oxygen to form water. This step is essential for oxidative phosphorylation and ATP generation.
  • ➤ Cytochrome aa₃ (cytochrome c oxidase, complex IV) is the terminal electron acceptor in the electron transport chain and directly reacts with molecular oxygen to form water.
  • ➤ Cytochrome aa₃ (cytochrome c oxidase, complex IV)
  • ➤ This step is essential for oxidative phosphorylation and ATP generation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset shortness of breath and sharp left-sided chest pain. He denies fever, loss of consciousness, or orthopnea. His medical history is significant for metastatic pancreatic cancer diagnosed three months ago. On examination, his lungs are clear, heart sounds are normal, and his abdomen is soft and non-tender. There is trace edema in the right leg, and neurologic examination is unremarkable. Laboratory findings reveal elevated serum troponin levels (0.9 ng/mL), normal complete blood count, and normal renal function. A right leg ultrasound reveals a thrombus in the popliteal vein, and a CT angiogram of the chest shows bilateral filling defects. Which of the following would be the most effective long-term treatment to prevent recurrent thromboembolism in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Enoxaparin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cancer-associated thromboembolism, LMWH is the treatment of choice for long-term prevention of recurrent thromboembolism due to its superior efficacy and safety profile compared to other anticoagulants.
  • ➤ In cancer-associated thromboembolism, LMWH is the treatment of choice for long-term prevention of recurrent thromboembolism due to its superior efficacy and safety profile compared to other anticoagulants.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the quadruple marker test?

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic patient presents with complaints of discoloration of his toenail for the past 4 months, as shown in the image below . Microscopic examination of a sample is shown below. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of his condition?

questions.text: A postmenopausal woman is being treated with exemestane for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. What is the most likely side effect associated with this medication?

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with shortness of breath and lower extremity swelling. On auscultation, a soft, low-pitched sound (S3) is heard after S2. This sound is closely associated with which phase of the cardiac cycle?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The S3 heart sound occurs during the rapid ventricular filling phase of diastole (passive atrial emptying) and is typically caused by sudden deceleration of blood into a distended or non-compliant ventricle.
  • ➤ The S3 heart sound occurs during the rapid ventricular filling phase of diastole (passive atrial emptying) and is typically caused by sudden deceleration of blood into a distended or non-compliant ventricle.

questions.text: A clinical trial evaluates the safety profile of a new medication compared to a placebo in preventing adverse events. The study enrolled 20,000 participants, evenly randomized into two groups (new drug vs. placebo). After one year of follow-up, 1,500 participants in the new drug group and 2,000 participants in the placebo group experienced adverse events. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most accurate calculation regarding the efficacy of the new drug?

options.label: A
options.text: The absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 5%, and the relative risk reduction (RRR) is 25%.

options.label: B
options.text: The absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 5%, and the number needed to treat (NNT) is 20.

options.label: C
options.text: The relative risk reduction (RRR) is 10%, and the number needed to treat (NNT) is 50.

options.label: D
options.text: The absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 10%, and the relative risk reduction (RRR) is 50%.

questions.correct_answer: B. The absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 5%, and the number needed to treat (NNT) is 20.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 5%, and the number needed to treat (NNT) is 20.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The absolute risk reduction (ARR), relative risk reduction (RRR), and number needed to treat (NNT) are critical measures used to evaluate the efficacy of an intervention. ARR provides the direct difference in risk, RRR highlights the proportional reduction in risk, and NNT quantifies the number of individuals needed to treat to prevent one adverse outcome. Accurate calculation of these measures is essential for understanding clinical trial results and their application in practice.
  • ➤ The absolute risk reduction (ARR), relative risk reduction (RRR), and number needed to treat (NNT) are critical measures used to evaluate the efficacy of an intervention. ARR provides the direct difference in risk, RRR highlights the proportional reduction in risk, and NNT quantifies the number of individuals needed to treat to prevent one adverse outcome.
  • ➤ Accurate calculation of these measures is essential for understanding clinical trial results and their application in practice.

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby presents with generalized seizures and irritability. The mother reports poor feeding and delayed developmental milestones. A detailed history and clinical findings suggest vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency as the cause of the seizures. Which of the following tests is most useful to confirm a diagnosis of vitamin B6 deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The xanthurenic acid test is used to diagnose vitamin B6 deficiency by measuring the accumulation of xanthurenic acid in the urine after a tryptophan load. In vitamin B6 deficiency, the impaired conversion of tryptophan leads to elevated urinary excretion of xanthurenic acid.
  • ➤ The xanthurenic acid test is used to diagnose vitamin B6 deficiency by measuring the accumulation of xanthurenic acid in the urine after a tryptophan load.
  • ➤ xanthurenic acid test
  • ➤ In vitamin B6 deficiency, the impaired conversion of tryptophan leads to elevated urinary excretion of xanthurenic acid.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is administered intradermally in the right upper arm during infancy?

questions.text: A 20-year-old college student is brought to the emergency department due to progressive lethargy and confusion. His friend reports a history of chills and diarrhea since last night. Three days ago, the patient sustained a nasal fracture during a bar fight, which was reduced and stabilized with nasal packing at another hospital. He has no known medical conditions, medications, or drug allergies. On examination, his temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), blood pressure is 84/42 mm Hg, pulse is 126/min, and respirations are 18/min. The patient appears ill with diffuse erythema involving mucous membranes, palms, and soles. Anterior nasal packing is visible in the left nostril, and there is mild pitting edema in both legs. Laboratory results reveal thrombocytopenia, acute kidney injury, hyponatremia, elevated liver enzymes, and metabolic acidosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial antimicrobial therapy for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vancomycin, cefepime, and clindamycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Toxic shock syndrome requires prompt recognition and treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including agents that inhibit toxin production (e.g., clindamycin). Nasal packing is a recognized risk factor for Staphylococcus aureus TSS. Rapid initiation of antibiotics and aggressive supportive care are essential to reduce mortality
  • ➤ Toxic shock syndrome requires prompt recognition and treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including agents that inhibit toxin production (e.g., clindamycin).
  • ➤ Nasal packing is a recognized risk factor for Staphylococcus aureus TSS.
  • ➤ Rapid initiation of antibiotics and aggressive supportive care are essential to reduce mortality

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is enrolled in a pharmacokinetics study. During the study, he is administered a drug that is known to follow first-order kinetics. The researchers measure the plasma concentration and clearance of the drug over time. Which of the following graphs correctly illustrates the relationship between clearance and plasma concentration for this drug?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In first-order kinetics, the clearance of a drug remains constant irrespective of plasma concentration, as a constant fraction of the drug is eliminated per unit time. This is in contrast to non-linear or zero-order kinetics, where clearance may change with plasma concentration due to saturation of metabolic or excretory pathways.
  • ➤ In first-order kinetics, the clearance of a drug remains constant irrespective of plasma concentration, as a constant fraction of the drug is eliminated per unit time.
  • ➤ This is in contrast to non-linear or zero-order kinetics, where clearance may change with plasma concentration due to saturation of metabolic or excretory pathways.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with muscle weakness, exercise intolerance, and failure to thrive. He also has a history of cardiomyopathy. questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with mid-abdominal pain and vomiting for two days, along with dark stools and decreased appetite. On examination, his temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg, and pulse is 98/min. The abdomen is mildly tender without rebound. A stool occult blood test is positive, and skin changes are shown below. Laboratory studies reveal mild anemia, normal platelets, and elevated ESR. Urinalysis shows proteinuria and hematuria. questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman with beta-thalassemia major is being treated with Deferiprone for transfusion-associated iron overload. However, its limited ability to target intracellular iron stored in tissues like the liver necessitates combination therapy in patients with significant hepatic iron overload.

questions.text: Mr. Sinha, 76-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with 6 hours of shortness of breath and chest pain. Hemodynamic readings from the pulmonary artery catheter are as follows: Right atrial pressure: 10 mm Hg Right ventricular pressure: 36/15 mm Hg Pulmonary artery pressure: 42/18 mm Hg Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure: 24 mm Hg Cardiac index: 1.5 L/min/m² Systemic vascular resistance: 1365 dynes/sec/cm⁵ Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s hypotension?

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman from an assisted living facility is brought to the emergency department after a tonic-clonic seizure. Her caretakers report mild confusion and headache yesterday, followed by involuntary shaking of her right upper and lower extremities before the seizure. The patient has no history of recent travel, sick contacts, or systemic symptoms like cough, diarrhea, or urinary issues. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia but no known allergies. On examination, her temperature is 38.1°C (100.8°F), blood pressure is 140/88 mm Hg, and pulse is 90/min. She is obtunded and does not follow commands but localizes pain bilaterally and withdraws her lower extremities to pain. Non-contrast CT of the head shows no mass, bleeding, or parenchymal abnormalities. MRI image is shown below. Chest X-ray and urinalysis are unremarkable. A lumbar puncture is attempted but unsuccessful. She is started on intravenous vancomycin, ampicillin, and ceftriaxone. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Perform MRI of the brain with and without gadolinium

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Add intravenous acyclovir

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HSV encephalitis should be suspected in patients with fever, altered mental status, focal neurological deficits, and seizures. Prompt initiation of intravenous acyclovir is critical, as delayed treatment can lead to severe neurological damage or death. MRI and lumbar puncture can help confirm the diagnosis but should not delay empiric treatment.
  • ➤ HSV encephalitis should be suspected in patients with fever, altered mental status, focal neurological deficits, and seizures.
  • ➤ Prompt initiation of intravenous acyclovir is critical, as delayed treatment can lead to severe neurological damage or death.
  • ➤ MRI and lumbar puncture can help confirm the diagnosis but should not delay empiric treatment.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman undergoes enucleation of her left eye following a severe penetrating injury sustained in a car accident. Two months later, she develops photophobia, blurring of vision, and floaters in her right (uninjured) eye. On examination, she has retrolental flare, vitreous cells, and clusters of pigmented epithelioid cells beneath the retinal pigment epithelium (Dalen-Fuchs nodules). What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate enucleation of the injured eye

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) High-dose systemic corticosteroids

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • High-dose systemic corticosteroids are the first-line treatment for sympathetic ophthalmia to control the immune-mediated inflammation. Enucleation of the injured eye is only preventive and effective within 2 weeks post-injury. Once the condition manifests, the goal is to preserve vision in the sympathizing eye using anti-inflammatory therapy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Immediate enucleation of the injured eye: This is ineffective for preventing the progression of sympathetic ophthalmia once it has already developed.
  • • Option A. Immediate enucleation of the injured eye:
  • • Option C. Vitrectomy and retinal detachment repair: This is used for mechanical retinal issues but not for immune-mediated uveitis.
  • • Option C. Vitrectomy and retinal detachment repair:
  • • Option D. Empiric antibiotic therapy for endophthalmitis: There is no evidence of an infectious process in this case.
  • • Option D. Empiric antibiotic therapy for endophthalmitis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sympathetic ophthalmia is treated with high-dose corticosteroids to suppress the immune response and prevent further vision loss.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with chronic kidney disease presents with worsening fatigue and signs of organ dysfunction. Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ferroptosis is a regulated form of cell death driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation and oxidative stress. It differs from apoptosis, necroptosis, and pyroptosis in that it involves extensive lipid membrane degradation without caspase activation or nuclear fragmentation. Elevated malondialdehyde (MDA) levels serve as a biomarker for lipid peroxidation in this process.
  • ➤ Ferroptosis is a regulated form of cell death driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation and oxidative stress.

  • ➤ It differs from apoptosis, necroptosis, and pyroptosis in that it involves extensive lipid membrane degradation without caspase activation or nuclear fragmentation.
  • ➤ Elevated malondialdehyde (MDA) levels serve as a biomarker for lipid peroxidation in this process.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with recurrent vertebral compression fractures and a diagnosis of osteoporosis. She is started on a bisphosphonate as part of her treatment. questions.text: While attending to a woman in active labor, a midwife identifies a prolapsed umbilical cord during a vaginal examination. What is the next immediate step in the management of this patient?

questions.text: Ms. Sreeja, 22-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with heavy vaginal bleeding that has persisted for 5 days. questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of dark-colored urine, fatigue, and jaundice. He has a history of cirrhosis secondary to chronic liver disease. questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 3-month history of persistent cough, low-grade fevers, night sweats, and hemoptysis. She reports unintentional weight loss. Chest X-ray reveals a cavitary lesion in the upper lobe of the right lung. A biopsy of the lesion shows caseous necrosis surrounded by epithelioid macrophages and multinucleated giant cells. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the tissue damage in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Type IV hypersensitivity reaction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type IV hypersensitivity reactions, mediated by CD4+ T-cells and macrophages, are the underlying mechanism for granuloma formation and tissue destruction in tuberculosis. Caseous necrosis is a distinctive finding due to the interaction of activated macrophages releasing ROS and proteolytic enzymes.
  • ➤ Type IV hypersensitivity reactions, mediated by CD4+ T-cells and macrophages, are the underlying mechanism for granuloma formation and tissue destruction in tuberculosis.
  • ➤ Caseous necrosis is a distinctive finding due to the interaction of activated macrophages releasing ROS and proteolytic enzymes.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset weakness on the right side of his body and difficulty speaking, which began one hour ago while he was at work. He has a history of secondary progressive multiple sclerosis diagnosed 30 years ago with multiple exacerbations, as well as hypertension and hyperlipidemia. On examination, he has weakness of the right lower face, right arm, and mild weakness of the right leg. His speech is limited to 1–2 words with great effort. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for the patient’s current presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Middle cerebral artery stroke

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sudden-onset focal neurological deficits, including hemiparesis and aphasia, are hallmarks of an ischemic stroke, particularly in the distribution of the middle cerebral artery. Acute management should include urgent neuroimaging and evaluation for thrombolysis or thrombectomy.
  • ➤ Sudden-onset focal neurological deficits, including hemiparesis and aphasia, are hallmarks of an ischemic stroke, particularly in the distribution of the middle cerebral artery.
  • ➤ Acute management should include urgent neuroimaging and evaluation for thrombolysis or thrombectomy.

questions.text: Consider the following statements regarding Schizophrenia and its clinical features: Statement 1: First-rank symptoms of schizophrenia include auditory hallucinations, thought insertion, and thought withdrawal. Statement 2: Schizophrenia has an earlier onset in males and is associated with a worse prognosis in females. Statement 3: Negative symptoms of schizophrenia include alogia, avolition, and affective flattening. Statement 4: Delusions of grandeur are more common in schizophrenia compared to delusions of persecution. Which of the following is correct?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Statements 1 and 3 are correct.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Schizophrenia is characterized by positive symptoms (e.g., hallucinations, delusions), negative symptoms (e.g., affective flattening, avolition), and cognitive impairments. First-rank symptoms are pathognomonic but not exclusive to schizophrenia.
  • ➤ Schizophrenia is characterized by positive symptoms (e.g., hallucinations, delusions), negative symptoms (e.g., affective flattening, avolition), and cognitive impairments. First-rank symptoms are pathognomonic but not exclusive to schizophrenia.
  • ➤ positive symptoms
  • ➤ negative symptoms

questions.text: A pediatric dermatologist is evaluating a 6-year-old boy with a history of atopic dermatitis who presents with clusters of umbilicated, flesh-colored papules around the flexor creases of his arms. The dermatologist notes that these lesions seem to spread along the lines of skin trauma. Which of the following mechanisms best explains this pattern of lesion distribution?

options.label: A
options.text: Hematogenous dissemination of the virus following initial inoculation

options.label: B
options.text: Local spread due to mechanical inoculation during scratching

options.label: C
options.text: Autoinoculation caused by viral shedding into sebaceous glands

options.label: D
options.text: Activation of latent virus in the surrounding skin cells

questions.correct_answer: B. Local spread due to mechanical inoculation during scratching
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Local spread due to mechanical inoculation during scratching

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Koebner phenomenon, seen in molluscum contagiosum, describes local spread of lesions along lines of trauma due to autoinoculation.
  • ➤ The Koebner phenomenon, seen in molluscum contagiosum, describes local spread of lesions along lines of trauma due to autoinoculation.

questions.text: In a town with a population of 200,000, a total of 40,000 blood slides were examined for malaria in one year, and 80 cases of malaria were confirmed. What is the Annual Parasite Incidence (API) in this town?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 0.4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ API is a measure of the incidence of malaria in a community and helps identify high-risk areas where vector control measures are necessary.
  • ➤ API is a measure of the incidence of malaria in a community and helps identify high-risk areas where vector control measures are necessary.

questions.text: A bone marrow biopsy is performed on a patient with pancytopenia to identify pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells. Which of the following markers is most specific for these cells?

questions.text: A patient with pulmonary arterial hypertension is prescribed a medication that increases the formation of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP). Which of the following adverse effects is most likely to occur with this medication?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hypotension
